div1.p: Hemphill is publishing an article on Walter Reed's years in Virginia and seeks photographs, as well as corrections to the manuscript, from Hench.

Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
In the Winter issue of our new pictorial, quarterly magazine
of Virginia history entitled Virginia Cavalcade we are expecting
to publish an article about the years of Walter Reed's residence
in Virginia which has been written by a member of my staff,
Mr. James H. Bailey. I am now rushing to obtain by loan and
otherwise pictures pertinent to that period of Reed's life which
will be suitable for reproduction as illustrations for this
article. Nothing is more natural under these circumstances than
that I should write to you and request any cooperation which you
may be able to give us.

In order that you may see our needs in best focus, I am
sending to you herewith a sample copy of our Autumn issue of
Virginia Cavalcade--to which, incidentally, the Mayo Clinic
Library, but not you or your brother, has subscribed. I am also
sending with this letter a carbon copy of the manuscript which
has gone to press for our article on the formative years of
Walter Reed in Virginia. Any comments or corrections which you
might make to improve the text of this article would be of
extreme value to us and would be gratefully welcomed as con-
structive criticism. At the end of the manuscript you will
notice a list of illustration possibilities; this list would
enable you to judge how you can assist us best in the provision
of pictures by loan or otherwise. If you should not dare to
lend to us some pertinent original print or similar item, perhaps
you could have a local photographer send to us an 8" x 10" glossy
print of it and bill us on a firm form for his service.

You cannot be expected to remember me, but I want you to
know that several members of my staff and I have pleasant
recollections of the occasions upon which you have talked about
Walter Reed in Charlottesville in recent years. Your brother
Dr. Philip S. Hench
